<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_finish:
```c
void metal_linux_bus_finish(void)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	for_each_linux_bus(lbus) {
		if (metal_bus_find(lbus->bus_name, &bus) == 0)
			metal_bus_unregister(bus);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only controlling expressions are the loop controlled by the for_each_linux_bus macro and the if condition. The if condition (metal_bus_find(lbus->bus_name, &bus) == 0) depends on the runtime value of lbus->bus_name and the result of metal_bus_find, so it is not invariant and does not need investigation for Rule 14.3. There are no other loop or conditional controlling expressions in this function. The declarations of lbus and bus are not controlling expressions. The for_each_linux_bus construct is a macro whose expansion may contain an invariant controlling expression (or an intentional infinite loop); its expansion should be inspected to verify compliance with Rule 14.3 and applicable exceptions, so the loop block above is reported for investigation.
